Award.AbstractNarration:
This research aims to understand the exciting array of experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Geneva and the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) in New York. Two particle correlation measurements and related fluctuation studies can reveal space-time information about particle production and dynamics not measured by single particle observables. The activity supported by this award centers on an innovative program to develop theoretical tools for the analysis of correlations in a hydrodynamic context. Applications of this framework to transverse-momentum fluctuation data already provide a first estimate of the shear viscosity.

RHIC experiments exhibit a striking "ridge" of enhanced correlations that has garnered substantial interest. This ridge occurs both with and without a jet trigger, and is part of a rich correlation landscape. We propose to apply our hydrodynamic framework to understand this landscape at RHIC and LHC. These efforts promise to reveal information on both early stages of particle production - the glasma - as well as the later period of hydrodynamic evolution. This and similar work is driven by data analyzed at Wayne State. Close collaboration with these experimenters puts this theory group in an excellent position to understand and influence such analyses.

The colliders RHIC and LHC smash nuclei together, producing a tiny fleeting soup of elementary particles called the quark-gluon plasma. By studying the fluid characteristics of this plasma using mathematical models, we hope to explain what is seen at these massive colliders. I'm especially excited to be sharing this research with disadvantaged students in Detroit through a program aimed at students who are studying to become teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Relativistic heavy ion collisions can create tiny short-lived samples of quark gluon plasma. Experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Geneva and the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) in New York report a range of measurements that indicate that the plasma flows like a fluid before it breaks up into protons, neutrons and other "ordinary" particles. The theoretical work in our program aims to explain the forces that give rise to this flow and, furthermore, to deliver quantitative information about the properties of the plasma. 

Correlation measurements can reveal space-time information about particle production and dynamics not measured by single particle observables. We have worked to develop theoretical tools for the analysis of correlations in a hydrodynamic context. Applications of our framework to measurements provide an estimate of the shear viscosity and other transport coefficients. 

Startling experimental results in proton-proton and proton-nucleus collisions indicate unanticipated flow phenomena. We developed new theoretical tools based on kinetic theory to study the onset of flow in proton-proton and proton-nucleus collisions. In collaboration with experimenters at Wayne State University and elsewhere, we are now using these tools to identify new methods for experiments to extract information about the origin of flow. 

We identified new features in data from RHIC Gold-Gold collisions that indicate that the time needed to bring about this flow is extremely short -- short enough for flow to take hold in proton collisions. Further results from kinetic theory indicate that the matter produced in proton collisions may approach thermal equilibrium, but only in head-on collisions.    

Broader Impacts: Our educational efforts provide for substantial participation of undergraduate and graduate students in research. Involvement with Wayne State's extensive NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program attracts students under-represented in the physical sciences. In addition, we are working to continue the development of an ambitious outreach initiative to encourage scientific literacy and public understanding of the scientific method.
